text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Jordanian press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
AL-RAI
- Crown Prince Hassan says Jordan's efforts to improve conditions for Palestinians in refugee camps does not contradict their right to return to their homeland.
- Prime Minister Abdul-Salam al-Majali, meeting a delegation of Israeli Arabs, says the fruits of peace are guaranteed.
- Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Prince Saud al-Feisal expected in Jordan today for talks with King Hussein.
- Opposition groups threaten to boycott elections and hold protest march on June 13 if government does not revoke amendments to press and publications law.
AL-DUSTOUR
- Palestinian President Yasser Arafat expected in Jordan within 48 hours for talks with King Hussein.
- Busy turnover in Jordan Cement and Jordan National Bank shares on stock exchange.
- Politicians say they want the palace to step in to resolve growing political contradictions in Jordan.
- Wihdat Football club declines to play in championship final.
AL-ARAB AL-YAWM
- French magazine says Jordanians are selling their U.N. licences for exports to Iraq to Turkish firms. Turkish cement exporters are buying the licences for $4 per tonne of exports.
- Jordan retains right to oppose anything which threatens national security in its negotiations with Israel for the joint "peace airport" near the Red Sea coast.
AL-ASWAQ
- Jordan, Bahrain agree joint aluminium project at trade show in Amman. Another 26 investment projects to be proposed today.
JORDAN TIMES
- King celebrates Independence Day with citizens of Balqa.
- Crown Prince Hassan and UNRWA head mark completion of UNRWA projects, hopeful that donor countries will help resolve the organisation's financial problems.
$1 = 0.709 dinars
